Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Multiplexed Diagnostic Platform for Rapid Diagnostics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Current commercial instruments in the diagnostic field usually lack one or more attributes in sample-to-answer systems, specifically: throughput, multiplexing, sensitivity, fast time to answer, and low-cost. The proposed technology attempts to develop a diagnostic platform that will address the key weaknesses in currently available technologies. The proposed diagnostic platform is based on an optical detection method termed Interferometric Reflectance Imaging Sensor (IRIS). IRIS has demonstrated single virus and single molecule (both protein & nucleic acids) detection in whole blood and serum at clinically relevant levels.

The proposed technology provides a turn-key solution for multiplexed sample-to-answer diagnostic tests. This automated technology can detect clinically relevant virus directly without a secondary tag or marker. It is believed that the proposed approach can be competitive with other systems (fundamentally simpler, reducing the costs of the instrument and consumable, allowing for competitively pricing the consumable and instrument). In addition to the pure economics of the system, the proposed technology will help perform detection in a small form-factor with minimal waste. Finally, the non-destructive sensing techniques allow storage of samples for further testing if desired.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many engineers come up with great ideas for new technologies, but often they don’t have enough business experience to successfully bring their products to market. Fortuitously, a team of engineers was able to participate in the National Science Foundation (NSF) Innovation Corps (I-Corps), a program that allows scientists and engineers to broaden their focus to look beyond lab work and develop their entrepreneurship training.

Specifically, the engineers had been trying to bring some of their ideas to a commercial state and the training they received allowed them to ask the tough questions about real market needs. By setting aside their technology and listening to over 100 people, they were able to formulate market pains and formulate viable solutions. Specifically, they validated value propositions of their technology via a metric based analysis with data collected by interviews of individual people.

The focus was on their technology, which is able to detect viruses and pathogens, and their initial hypothesis is that this technology might be applied in doctors’ offices, hospitals, and emergency care centers. By focusing on the customer pains with existing technologies, it was possible to determine how these pains could be alleviated.

By finding out what people really needed before developing a technology, the development of a product is setup to succeed as opposed to setup to fail. Much of the knowledge gained through I-Corps will be used to advance science and engineering research. Some products tested during the workshops even show immediate market potential by the conclusion of the curriculum.
